2.text:
A petition is a way of getting your voice
heard in Parliament. It’s a written request

6.text:
asking the House of Commons, or the Government,
to take action on something. You prepare your

11.text:
petition and get people who agree with you
to sign it. There are some kinds of petition

16.text:
we can’t accept. Have a look on our web
page to make sure. You can always get in touch

21.text:
with us to clarify before you start work.
You can send us two types of petition.

27.text:
A paper petition or an online e-petition. A paper
petition asks the House of Commons to do something.

34.text:
For example, make a new law or amend an existing
one, or put pressure on the Government to

40.text:
take action on a particular issue. Paper petitions
are normally from a local area. This isn’t

46.text:
a rule but you will need to collect hand-signed
signatures which is obviously easier to do

52.text:
close to home. Once your paper petition is
ready you need to find an MP willing to present

59.text:
it to the House of Commons. An online e-petition
can ask the Government as well as the Commons

67.text:
to do something. If your issue is national
then this is the best way to get signatures

74.text:
from around the country as you will be putting
your petition online for anyone to sign. You

79.text:
can browse the e-petitions website for other
petitions and sign any which you strongly

83.text:
agree with. So what happens next? The Petitions
Committee, that’s a group of MPs from different

90.text:
parties, will decide if they want to investigate
your petition. In other words they might want

95.text:
to find out more information from the public,
or experts or from the Government or have

100.text: a debate on it in the House of Commons. E-petitions that receive 100,000 signatures

107.text:
will definitely be considered for a debate.
Most paper petitions receive a response from

112.text:
the Government as do all e-petitions which
receive 10,000 signatures or more. All petitions

118.text:
are recorded in the official record of Parliament.
Whatever happens, even if your petition does

125.text:
not get picked up by Parliament for debate,
you will certainly have helped get publicity

129.text:
for your campaign. You may decide to stop
there or continue campaigning in other ways.

136.text:
Just remember, the most famous campaigns in
history often started with a petition.
